validation_metadata.verification_method: Direct review of Iowa Code Chapter 22

rights_of_access.subcategory: Right to Examine, Copy, and Disseminate
rights_of_access.description: Every person has the right to examine, copy, and disseminate public records unless they fall under limited exceptions. This establishes Iowa's presumption of openness.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to all persons; no residency requirement; no purpose statement required; no use restrictions
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Triple right - examine, copy, AND disseminate; supports transparency journalism and citizen oversight; no restrictions on use of obtained records
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'Iowa Code Chapter 22 grants me the right to examine, copy, and disseminate [records]. Please provide access under this statutory right.'

rights_of_access.description: Response should not exceed 20 calendar days and ordinarily should not exceed 10 business days. No set deadline for deemed denial.
rights_of_access.conditions: Ordinarily 10 business days; should not exceed 20 calendar days; flexible standard based on request complexity
rights_of_access.applies_to: All open records requests in Iowa
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Dual timeline - ordinary (10 business days) and maximum (20 calendar days); provides flexibility while capping delays
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite timeline: 'Iowa Code § 22.4 provides records ordinarily within 10 business days, not exceeding 20 calendar days. Please confirm expected production date within these timeframes.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies may charge reasonable fees for copying and processing but fees cannot exceed actual costs incurred. Cannot include overhead or administrative costs - only direct expenses for supervision, making copies, and providing copies.
rights_of_access.conditions: Limited to actual costs only; no overhead charges; covers supervision, copying, and provision; must be reasonable and directly attributable
rights_of_access.applies_to: All fee charges for Iowa public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Strong cost limitation - prevents agencies from inflating fees with overhead; focuses on true marginal costs of fulfilling request
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge fees: 'Iowa Code § 22.3 limits fees to actual costs without overhead or administrative charges. Please provide fee breakdown showing only direct costs for supervision and copying.'

rights_of_access.description: Iowa Public Information Board (IPIB) handles complaints about violations, issues formal opinions, can recommend removal of officials from office, and provides guidance. File complaint within 60 days of alleged violation.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must file within 60 days; IPIB investigates and determines; can recommend official removal; provides expert administrative oversight
rights_of_access.applies_to: Alleged open records violations in Iowa
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Independent enforcement board with meaningful authority; formal opinions have precedential value; removal power creates accountability
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert IPIB appeal: 'I may file a complaint with the Iowa Public Information Board within 60 days under Iowa Code § 23. Please reconsider or I will pursue IPIB review.'

rights_of_access.description: Mandamus action and injunctive relief available in district court. Court may award attorney's fees and costs in some cases.
rights_of_access.conditions: District court jurisdiction; mandamus or injunctive relief; discretionary attorney fees
rights_of_access.applies_to: Open records violations requiring judicial intervention
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Traditional judicial remedies available; attorney fee provision helps offset litigation costs for meritorious cases
rights_of_access.request_tips: Warn of judicial option: 'Iowa law provides for mandamus and injunctive relief in district court, with potential attorney fees. Please provide lawful access to avoid litigation.'

rights_of_access.description: Exemptions in Iowa are discretionary, not mandatory, and should be construed narrowly in favor of disclosure. Agencies have discretion to release even when exemption applies.
rights_of_access.conditions: Exemptions are permissive, not mandatory; agencies should construe narrowly; discretion to release exempt records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Empowers agencies to choose transparency; exemptions are ceilings not floors; encourages disclosure even when withholding technically permitted
rights_of_access.request_tips: Encourage disclosure: 'Iowa Code § 22.7 exemptions are discretionary and should be construed narrowly. I request you exercise discretion in favor of disclosure.'
